3. Shifts costs to owners: Rent control limits the profitability of rental properties, leading landlords to cut back on maintenance and upgrades. This can result in deteriorating housing quality over time, especially in older rent-controlled buildings.

In summary, while rent control provides important short-term benefits to tenants in terms of price stability and preventing displacement, the strongest evidence suggests that it has negative effects on overall housing affordability and supply in the long run by distorting market signals and reducing the incentive to build and maintain rental units.
